thread.title: Bride who lost 150-year-old wedding dress handmade by great-great-grandmother has it back after viral appeal
thread.title_full: Bride who lost 150-year-old wedding dress handmade by great-great-grandmother has it back after viral appeal

author: Rohese Devereux Taylor
title: Bride who lost 150-year-old wedding dress handmade by great-great-grandmother has it back after viral appeal
text:
Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
A bride who lose her precious wedding dress at the dry cleaners has been reunited with it after a Facebook appeal went viral. 
Tess Newall, took to social media for help to track down the 150-year-old dress - handmade by her great-great-grandmother Dora in 1870. 
It had vanished from the premises of an Edinburgh firm that had been placed in administration, report the Daily Record. 
Concerned that the lace gown had been sold, Tess launched an online appeal in a bid to track it down. Tess in her great-great-grandmother Dora's dress (Photo: Facebook) Bride's joy as antique wedding dress lost by dry cleaners is found after Facebook appeal goes viral (Photo: Tess Newall Facebook) Read More Heartbroken bride's desperate appeal to find antique wedding dress lost after 'dry cleaner sold it' 
Her emotional post was shared nearly 300,000 times on Facebook. 
But the dress has now been found in the closed shop "in a crumpled heap on the floor." 
Tess wrote: "IT'S BEEN FOUND." 
In the updated post she revealed that the administrators dealing with troubled firm Kleen Cleaners had told her that her dress was not in the shop but the kind-hearted landlord decided to double check the premises after reading of her plight. (Photo: Facebook) 
She told how, to her "amazement and joy", her beloved dress was indeed there and that her parents had been in to confirm it. Read More Lauren Goodger is ALREADY shopping for wedding dresses as sheâ€™s convinced jailbird boyfriend will propose 
The dress is not yet safely back in the arms of its owner as administrators Wylie & Bisset insist that for "procedural reasons" the dress has to go back to Glasgow first. 
Tess added: "My family can't thank you all enough for creating this frenzy which allowed us into the shop before it was cleared, and are over the moon to be *almost* reunited with Dora's dress. 
"I am completely ecstatic. I never thought people would be so kind to help and care about something so precious to me. Thanks to all the Bridebook.co.uk brides and team for leading the charge on the search. I'm never letting the dress out of my sight again!" 
The 29-year-old walked down the aisle in the altered family heirloom to marry Alfred Newall in a church in Morham, East Lothian, last June. Like us on Facebook
